Situation1: They have a serious conversation about financial or health decisions that require full transparency and mutual understanding.
Situation2: They plan to attend a family ceremony, making sure to arrive on time and wear appropriate attire.
Story: I sat at the edge of our bed, my hands twisting the end of my dupatta. My husband’s voice echoed in my mind—he wanted to talk tonight, to finally lay everything out about our finances. He’d asked for honesty, for us to be open, to share every worry and hope. As his wife, I owed him that. But my phone buzzed again: my mother reminding me that the family puja was starting soon, and I needed to be there, dressed in my sari, ready to help with the rituals. It was an important festival, and as a Hindu daughter-in-law, my presence was expected, my participation a sign of respect and devotion. I felt pulled in two directions—toward the living room where my husband waited, and toward the temple room where my family gathered. My heart pounded with guilt and anxiety, knowing I couldn’t give both roles what they demanded at the same time.
